Factors that contributed to the shift from rural living to urban living during the British Industrial Revolution include:

1. Economic Opportunities: The industrial revolution led to an increase in factory work as businesses and industries began producing goods on a large scale. Many people saw these factories as a chance for better wages, more job security, and improved working conditions compared with farming.

2. Technological Advancements: New inventions like steam engines, spinning jennies, power looms, and railroads transformed agriculture and transportation of goods. This made it easier for farmers to sell their products in larger markets but also reduced labor requirements in rural areas.

3. Agricultural Innovations: As new agricultural techniques were implemented – such as crop rotation or selective breeding – farmers could produce more food using less land and fewer workers. This increased productivity meant that fewer farm laborers were needed over time.

4. Population Growth: The overall population of Great Britain was growing rapidly due in part to rising birth rates and declining death rates due to improvements in public health measures (such as vaccinations) during this period . More people sought work opportunities outside their village or town because there just wasn't enough employment available within their local communities anymore .

5. Urbanization Policies & Infrastructure Development- Government policies aimed at promoting urban growth , such infrastructure schemes like construction roads & canals connecting cities together made it easy accessibly thus attracting people migrate towards them . 

6.Crowded Living Conditions - Due overcrowding many countryside residents encouraged leave seek better quality life big towns .
